meta.title: Hip Migration Surveillance — Institution Lattice (Wisdom → Standards → Practice → Cases)
meta.subtitle: A layered map from implementation wisdom down to standards, practices, and concrete cases for automated hip migration assessment in CP surveillance.
meta.domainName: clinical AI for paediatric hip surveillance
meta.userContextPlaceholder: Describe your deployment setting (sites, scanners, workflow, stakeholders, constraints)…

levels.title: Wisdom (north star)
levels.hint: General guidance that shapes everything downstream.

levels.title: Principles & goals
levels.hint: What ‘good’ looks like in clinical implementation and surveillance.

levels.title: Core concepts (institution primitives)
levels.hint: Key entities and relationships from the Goguen institution.

levels.title: Mechanisms & levers
levels.hint: Cause–effect links: QC → reliability; validation → generalization; fit → adoption.

levels.title: Standards & frameworks
levels.hint: Formal standards/guidelines supporting safety, evidence, software, and interoperability.

levels.title: Practices & artefacts
levels.hint: Operational methods: datasets, annotation, monitoring, documentation, integration.

levels.title: Cases & challenges
levels.hint: Concrete scenarios, bottlenecks, and failure modes in real deployment.

nodes.label: Start with the problem, not the solution
nodes.summary: Clinical implementation succeeds when the clinical need drives the technology choices.
nodes.bodyHtml: Key message from the talk. Avoid building a highly accurate method and then searching for an application. Begin by understanding the clinical bottleneck and co-design a solution that fits real workflows.

nodes.label: Engage stakeholders early and continuously
nodes.summary: Clinicians, patients/carers, regulators, and engineers shape adoption and safety.
nodes.bodyHtml: Key message from the talk. Engagement should run from problem framing through evaluation and deployment, ensuring the solution remains useful, safe, and usable.

nodes.label: Communicate transparently and manage expectations
nodes.summary: External collaborations work when goals, risks, and timelines are explicit.
nodes.bodyHtml: Effective translation depends on shared language across technical experts, clinicians, patients, and regulators. Transparency reduces surprises and rework.

nodes.label: Prevent hip dislocation via surveillance
nodes.summary: Regular monitoring enables earlier intervention and avoids invasive surgery.
nodes.bodyHtml: Regular monitoring enables earlier intervention and avoids invasive surgery.

nodes.label: Reduce the manual measurement bottleneck
nodes.summary: Automation aims to shorten delays between imaging and recorded measurements.
nodes.bodyHtml: Automation aims to shorten delays between imaging and recorded measurements.

nodes.label: Use clinical data for clinical tools
nodes.summary: Tools should be trained/assessed on the data they will face in practice.
nodes.bodyHtml: Tools should be trained/assessed on the data they will face in practice.

nodes.label: Build trust through independent & external validation
nodes.summary: Demonstrate generalization to new hospitals/scanners/populations.
nodes.bodyHtml: Demonstrate generalization to new hospitals/scanners/populations.

nodes.label: Patient (child with CP)
nodes.summary: The subject of surveillance, with age/sex/diagnosis metadata.
nodes.bodyHtml: The subject of surveillance, with age/sex/diagnosis metadata.

nodes.label: Clinical hip X‑ray image
nodes.summary: Real-world imaging input: variable resolution, positioning, and labels.
nodes.bodyHtml: Real-world imaging input: variable resolution, positioning, and labels.

nodes.label: Quality control (QC) status
nodes.summary: Screening step that determines whether an image is usable for training/evaluation.
nodes.bodyHtml: Screening step that determines whether an image is usable for training/evaluation.

nodes.label: Clinician ground truth landmarks
nodes.summary: Expert-placed points defining anatomy for learning and evaluation.
nodes.bodyHtml: Expert-placed points defining anatomy for learning and evaluation.

nodes.label: ML landmark predictor
nodes.summary: Learns to place points on new images to enable measurement.
nodes.bodyHtml: Learns to place points on new images to enable measurement.

nodes.label: Geometric migration measurement
nodes.summary: Clinically relevant measurements computed from landmarks.
nodes.bodyHtml: Clinically relevant measurements computed from landmarks.

nodes.label: Surveillance database record (CPIP)
nodes.summary: Stores measurements over time for patient care and reporting.
nodes.bodyHtml: Stores measurements over time for patient care and reporting.

nodes.label: Validation report (internal vs external)
nodes.summary: Evidence artifact describing performance and generalization.
nodes.bodyHtml: Evidence artifact describing performance and generalization.

nodes.label: Clinical adoption & sustained use
nodes.summary: Whether the tool is actually used in practice.
nodes.bodyHtml: Whether the tool is actually used in practice.

nodes.label: Medical device regulatory pathway
nodes.summary: Translational step requiring processes, documentation, and often a commercial partner.
nodes.bodyHtml: Translational step requiring processes, documentation, and often a commercial partner.

nodes.label: Messy clinical data → failure modes
nodes.summary: Variability, label noise, shielding, pain positioning, and truncation degrade performance.
nodes.bodyHtml: Clinical images vary widely. Common issues: wrong label (knee vs hip), wrong side, obstruction by shield, part outside field of view, atypical positioning due to pain.

nodes.label: QC gating improves usable data
nodes.summary: More QC reduces harmful inputs reaching the model and evaluation.
nodes.bodyHtml: More QC reduces harmful inputs reaching the model and evaluation.

nodes.label: Ground truth scarcity limits learning
nodes.summary: Without enough expert labels, ML cannot robustly learn rare/edge cases.
nodes.bodyHtml: Without enough expert labels, ML cannot robustly learn rare/edge cases.

nodes.label: Landmarks → measurement → reporting
nodes.summary: Point predictions are transformed into clinically meaningful measurements and sent to database.
nodes.bodyHtml: Point predictions are transformed into clinically meaningful measurements and sent to database.

nodes.label: External validation tests distribution shift
nodes.summary: New hospitals/scanners/populations can change performance.
nodes.bodyHtml: New hospitals/scanners/populations can change performance.

nodes.label: Workflow fit drives adoption
nodes.summary: If it doesn’t fit clinician workflows, it won’t be used even if accurate.
nodes.bodyHtml: If it doesn’t fit clinician workflows, it won’t be used even if accurate.

nodes.label: PPIE → longitudinal growth‑chart outputs
nodes.summary: Parents/carers value trends over time; informs product requirements.
nodes.bodyHtml: Parents/carers value trends over time; informs product requirements.

nodes.label: Staged funding + perseverance
nodes.summary: Use smaller grants to gather data/evidence, then iterate towards larger funding.
nodes.bodyHtml: Use smaller grants to gather data/evidence, then iterate towards larger funding.

nodes.label: ISO 13485 (Medical device QMS)
nodes.summary: Quality management system requirements for medical devices.
nodes.bodyHtml: Quality management system requirements for medical devices.

nodes.label: ISO 14971 (Risk management for medical devices)
nodes.summary: Process for identifying hazards, evaluating and controlling risks.
nodes.bodyHtml: Process for identifying hazards, evaluating and controlling risks.

nodes.label: IEC 62304 (Medical device software lifecycle)
nodes.summary: Lifecycle processes for medical device software (planning→maintenance).
nodes.bodyHtml: Lifecycle processes for medical device software (planning→maintenance).

nodes.label: NICE Evidence Standards Framework (digital health)
nodes.summary: Evidence expectations for clinical and economic evaluation of digital health technologies.
nodes.bodyHtml: Evidence expectations for clinical and economic evaluation of digital health technologies.

nodes.label: CONSORT‑AI & SPIRIT‑AI (trial reporting)
nodes.summary: Reporting guidance for clinical trials involving AI interventions.
nodes.bodyHtml: Reporting guidance for clinical trials involving AI interventions.

nodes.label: CLAIM (AI in medical imaging reporting checklist)
nodes.summary: Checklist for reporting AI medical imaging studies.
nodes.bodyHtml: Checklist for reporting AI medical imaging studies.

nodes.label: DICOM (medical imaging interoperability)
nodes.summary: Standard for storing/transmitting medical images and related information.
nodes.bodyHtml: Standard for storing/transmitting medical images and related information.

nodes.label: HL7 FHIR (clinical data exchange)
nodes.summary: Standard for exchanging healthcare information electronically.
nodes.bodyHtml: Standard for exchanging healthcare information electronically.

nodes.label: QC protocol & audit trail
nodes.summary: Define screening rules, record exclusions, and track QC decisions.
nodes.bodyHtml: Define screening rules, record exclusions, and track QC decisions.

nodes.label: Clinician annotation workflow
nodes.summary: Create landmark ground truth with inter-rater checks and clear definitions.
nodes.bodyHtml: Create landmark ground truth with inter-rater checks and clear definitions.

nodes.label: Internal validation against clinical ground truth
nodes.summary: Compare tool vs expert measurements on local clinical data.
nodes.bodyHtml: Compare tool vs expert measurements on local clinical data.

nodes.label: External multi-site validation
nodes.summary: Test on data from other hospitals/scanners/populations.
nodes.bodyHtml: Test on data from other hospitals/scanners/populations.

nodes.label: Database integration & longitudinal dashboards
nodes.summary: Automate reporting and provide trend views for clinicians/carers.
nodes.bodyHtml: Automate reporting and provide trend views for clinicians/carers.

nodes.label: Post-deployment monitoring (drift + safety)
nodes.summary: Track drift and anomalies; maintain human oversight and feedback loops.
nodes.bodyHtml: Track drift and anomalies; maintain human oversight and feedback loops.

nodes.label: Technical & clinical documentation pack
nodes.summary: Model card, data sheet, intended use, risk file, validation dossier.
nodes.bodyHtml: Model card, data sheet, intended use, risk file, validation dossier.

nodes.label: Case: CP hip surveillance manual backlog
nodes.summary: Months-long delays between X-ray acquisition and recorded measurements.
nodes.bodyHtml: Months-long delays between X-ray acquisition and recorded measurements.

nodes.label: Case: External validation on Scotland data
nodes.summary: Independent site testing provides evidence of generalization.
nodes.bodyHtml: Independent site testing provides evidence of generalization.

nodes.label: Risk: Mislabelled exams (hip vs knee; left vs right)
nodes.summary: Label noise causes incorrect training/evaluation and unsafe outputs.
nodes.bodyHtml: Label noise causes incorrect training/evaluation and unsafe outputs.

nodes.label: Risk: Shielding/obstruction or out-of-FOV anatomy
nodes.summary: Missing anatomy prevents correct landmarking and measurement.
nodes.bodyHtml: Missing anatomy prevents correct landmarking and measurement.

nodes.label: Risk: Workflow mismatch (accurate but unused)
nodes.summary: A tool that doesn’t fit practice won’t be adopted.
nodes.bodyHtml: A tool that doesn’t fit practice won’t be adopted.

nodes.label: Risk: Distribution shift across scanners/hospitals
nodes.summary: New protocols and populations can degrade performance.
nodes.bodyHtml: New protocols and populations can degrade performance.

edges.why: Problem-first thinking anchors the work on preventing dislocation, not on maximizing benchmark scores.
The ‘problem’ includes timeliness and workflow friction, so automation must target delay reduction.
Engagement supports realistic evaluation goals and builds trust via independent evidence.
Service input clarifies what clinical data look like and which constraints matter.
Clear expectations across teams reduce stalled handoffs that prolong reporting delays.
The surveillance target is the child with CP, tracked longitudinally.
Prevention depends on measuring migration and acting on trends.
Shorter delays require faster recording into the surveillance database.
Clinical tools must handle the variability of real clinical X-rays.
Trust is formalized through internal and external validation reports.
Clinical X-rays exhibit variability and errors that create failure modes.
QC determines which images are safe/usable for training and measurement.
Clinician labels are costly; scarcity limits learning and evaluation.
Landmark predictions are the basis for automated geometric measurement.
Measurements are computed from landmarks and forwarded downstream.
External validation probes generalization under distribution shift.
Adoption is primarily governed by workflow fit and trust.
Regulatory readiness depends heavily on generalization evidence.
Growth-chart style outputs can improve fit for families and clinicians.
Messy data includes label noise (hip vs knee; left vs right).
Messy data includes obstruction/truncation and pain-positioning issues.
If clinical trials are run, AI-specific trial reporting guidance improves transparency.
Imaging-AI reporting checklists help document data, methods, and evaluation clearly.
QC is a risk control that mitigates hazards from bad inputs and must be justified.
Evidence/value frameworks shape what outcomes and usability matter.
QMS requirements govern controlled development for regulated medical devices.
Medical device software lifecycle processes structure development and maintenance.
Clinical data exchange is supported by interoperability standards like FHIR.
Medical images are typically managed and exchanged using DICOM.
Risk management identifies hazards; QC protocol implements input-risk controls with traceability.
Software lifecycle processes require documented requirements, verification, and maintenance artefacts.
QMS demands controlled documentation, design controls, and evidence of compliance.
Trial reporting standards encourage explicit evaluation protocols and endpoints.
Reporting checklists help structure reproducible internal validation.
Reporting checklists also apply to external validation descriptions.
Imaging interoperability requires consistent metadata handling and QC of incoming studies.
FHIR-style interfaces can support reliable database/EHR integration and reporting workflows.
Evidence standards influence what outcomes and economic considerations to assess.
QC checks catch mislabels and prevent incorrect training/measurement.
QC detects obstruction/out-of-FOV studies so they are excluded or flagged.
Automation + integration directly targets the manual backlog and reporting delays.
External validation practice produces multi-site evidence of generalization.
Monitoring detects drift/shift after deployment and triggers mitigation.
Clear intended use, limitations, and training materials reduce workflow mismatch risk.
Poor fit is a failure mode even with high accuracy.
Distribution shift is revealed by external validation and must be managed.
The manual backlog case motivates the project and defines success metrics.
Cross-site partnerships enable external validation cases and credible translation.
